name: Red-whiskered Bulbul
description: A small songbird, brown above, white below, with beige flanks. Distinctive features include red cheeks and underbelly and a tall, pointed black crest.
spread_note: South Asia, introduced elsewhere, such as Australia and Florida
food_note: Berries and other fruits, nectar, insects
image_alt: Red-whiskered bulbul, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
reproduction: Females lay 3–5 eggs, incubating them for 12–14 days.
attractions: It loves perching high in trees, hidden among foliage, singing loudly. Its nest is cup-shaped, woven from fine grasses and reinforced with bark and twigs. Both parents feed the chicks, initially with caterpillars and insects, later with berries.
breeding: We have kept them since 2004, when a pair arrived from Plzeň Zoo and successfully nested that same year.
